Amendments to Title 18 include the revision of Section 3144 to address the release or detention of a material witness in criminal cases before a court of the United States. A judicial officer may order the arrest of a material witness if there is probable cause to believe their testimony is essential and they have failed to appear after being served with a summons or subpoena. A judicial officer may issue a warrant for a material witness if they fail to appear after being served with a summons or subpoena. The warrant must contain the witness's name or a description to identify them. The officer can waive the summons or subpoena requirement if there is clear evidence that it may result in the person fleeing or not appearing as required. A warrant for a material witness must contain the witness's name or a description for identification, specify the testimony is for a criminal case, command the witness's arrest, inform them of their right to counsel, and be signed by a judicial officer. Upon arrest, an officer possessing the warrant must show it to the material witness. If the officer does not have the warrant at the time of arrest, they must inform the witness of its existence and purpose. Upon executing a warrant issued for a material witness, the officer must inform the witness of the warrant's existence and purpose. The officer should return the warrant to the judicial officer after execution, or at the request of the United States Government attorney for an unexecuted warrant. Upon executing a warrant for a material witness, the officer must inform the witness and return the warrant to the judicial officer. An unexecuted warrant can be canceled upon request by the US Government attorney. The material witness must be brought before a judicial officer without delay after arrest, either in the district of arrest or an adjacent district. At the initial appearance of a material witness arrested under a warrant, they must be brought before a judicial officer in the district of arrest or an adjacent district promptly. The judicial officer will inform the witness of the warrant, application, and affidavit filed in support of the warrant. At the initial appearance, a judicial officer must inform a material witness of the warrant, application, and affidavit. The witness has the right to counsel and can request counsel if needed. They are allowed to consult with counsel and may be released or detained as per the law. If the initial appearance is in a different district, the witness may be transferred there if deemed necessary by the judicial officer. Upon initial appearance, a material witness arrested under a warrant may be transferred to a different district if deemed necessary by the judicial officer. The officer must order the release or detention of the witness, with options for release on personal recognizance or bond. The release of a material witness arrested under a warrant may be on personal recognizance, unsecured appearance bond, or conditions determined by the judicial officer. Testimony can be secured by deposition if the witness cannot comply with release conditions. Detention may occur if there is no reasonable assurance of appearance. Detention of a material witness may occur if no conditions assure their appearance, allowing detention for up to 5 days or until testimony can be secured by deposition or court appearance. Detention of a material witness can be extended for up to 5 days or until testimony is secured by deposition or court appearance. The detention of a material witness can be extended for up to 30 days in a criminal case or 10 days in a grand jury proceeding, with a motion demonstrating good cause required. In a criminal case, the detention of a material witness can be extended for up to 30 days, or 10 days in a grand jury proceeding, with a motion showing good cause needed. Factors considered for release or detention include the witness's history and characteristics, and challenges to the warrant may be considered. The release order must specify the conditions of release. In a criminal case, the detention of a material witness can be extended for up to 30 days, or 10 days in a grand jury proceeding, with a motion showing good cause needed. Factors considered for release or detention include the witness's history and characteristics, challenges to the warrant may be considered. The release order must specify the conditions of release, and a detention order must comply with specific requirements for holding a material witness separately and under the least restrictive conditions possible. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to Congress on the use of detaining material witnesses, including the number of warrants sought and granted or denied. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to Congress on the use of detaining material witnesses, including the number of warrants sought, granted or denied, reasons for testimony not secured, and average detention days. Rule 46(h) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to supervise detention pending trial effectively. Amendment to Rule 46(h) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure requires the court to supervise detention within the district of defendants awaiting trial and material witnesses to eliminate unnecessary detention.
